comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: NLI yer wicked!  I was thinking the same but wondered if ironing silk is that easy - or was way back then before computerised electric irons?  Interesting that they had an enterprise like that in a city.  Interesting that they have/had a Railway Square on that side of the river given that the railway is on the Kilkenny side or in "Christendom" according to the google map?  Does that make my friends from Waterford benighted heathens then????

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Railway Square in | Manor Street in Waterford was the city terminus of the Tramore Railway. The Widger family had a very large house(one of many as they were very extensive horse exporters) and stables in Railway Square. These were demolished for road widening in 1980 c. The Widger family had  a horse that won the Grand national in 1896 I think. It was called Wild Man from Borneo.Widger family still are butchers in Michael Street Waterford and have large farm outside the city in Lacken.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Lovely up-to-date info on the Widgers. And it was 1895 that Wild Man won the Grand National. Think I'll add a pic of him over the next few days, so keep an eye out...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41820879@N05
comment._content: It was Wild man of Borneo that won the Grand National...trained by Jack Widger and ridden by Joe.   Great great Grand uncles of mine.
